Our nation was 2.5 million people on 1776. Now it is 330 million. In some ways our creation was less of a birth and more of a Big Bang. Something that set into motion progression beyond the wildest imagination of our founding fathers. 9/10 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FW2bAE6XgAMLV7W.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FW2bAFpXkAALYRy.jpg
Down the hall was the first gathering place for our Senate and the room where George Washington was sworn in for his second term as President. 8/10 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FW2a_sEXwAEMp1u.jpg

Independence Hall wasn’t just the birthplace of our nation, it was our home during our toddler years as we sought to keep this new nation united not around the power of a monarchy but around the shared idea of liberty. This is the Senate chamber from the very beginning. 7/10 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FW2a_QXWIAEbNNN.jpg

It’s here by Speaker’s chair that John Adams was sworn is as President, marking the first peaceful transfer of power. Something we failed to accomplish in 2021. Let us commit ourselves to never let that happen again and to live up to the examples of our founding fathers. 6/10 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FW2a-wfXkAQBxTH.jpg

Today was my first time seeing Congress Hall, which had the very first House of Representatives of our country, over 230 yrs before I had the chance to serve in the House. It was humbling to see where those that had my job began. 5/10 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FW2a-NaXoAAw_kY.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FW2a-O4XwAcWTd1.jpg

George Washington’s chair had carving of a sun. Ben Franklin said “I have often looked at that picture behind the president without being able to tell whether it was rising or setting. But now at length I have the happiness to know that it is a rising and not a setting sun.”4/10 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FW2a9zlX0AAW7Wk.jpg

Our Founding Fathers gathered here from all corners of the colonies. They had courage because of their convictions and the injustices they witnessed and experienced. But their power came from their unity. 3/10 http://pbs.twimg.com/ext_tw_video_thumb/1544060542435950593/pu/img/LdoHUtJDocSzOaBt.jpg https://video.twimg.com/ext_tw_video/1544060542435950593/pu/vid/480x270/nm9b7G0LN427gxrN.mp4?tag=12

The Declaration of Independence wasn’t signed in a palace or a castle. It was signed in this humble building by people who risked their lives by defying the most powerful person in the world. 2/10 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FW2a1zqXwAAe7lN.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FW2a16OWIAETtzU.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FW2a17oWIAILVvq.jpg

This is the room. The room where the Declaration of Independence was signed. Where the Constitution was debated and signed. Where the American flag was adopted. Where US Army was created.
